newsitem.title: USA: Kansas City, Mo., mulls bond, sales tax referenda.
newsitem.headline: Kansas City, Mo., mulls bond, sales tax referenda.

text.p: Kansas City, Mo., City Council next week will consider placing referendums for $125 million of wastewater treatment bonds and a half-cent sales tax hike on the November ballot, a mayoral assistant said Thursday.

The two referendum proposals discussed by a council committee on Wednesday are expected to be considered by the City Council at its Aug. 21 meeting, said Greg Lever, a legislative affairs assistant for Mayor Emanuel Cleaver.

Proceeds from the $125 million of wastewater revenue bonds would be used for capital improvements to the sewer system, city water department spokeswoman Colleen Newman said. If placed on the ballot and approved, it would be the first wastewater debt issuance since $66 million of bonds were approved in 1988, she said.
Cleaver has recommended asking voters to approve the separate half-cent sales tax hike to generate revenue for ongoing capital improvements without issuing debt, Lever said.
Proceeds from the sales tax hike, which excludes food, would be split between storm water management improvements in the water department and the city parks and recreation department, Newman said.
The deadline for submitting ballot referendums for the Nov. 4 election is Aug. 26, Lever said.
